body: Check your config, you probably have two folders with the same id. If you need more help, use the forum.

Hi @AudriusButkevicius and thanks for your prompt answer, greatly appreciated!

I though id were auto-generated, I just checked android-side and (if I get it right) I have 4 shares, which ids are:

- nexus_6p-photos
- default
- mv3sz-cniao
- 5z1xy-bg5iv

I don't know how to check the ids on my computer as the app won't start from now, but the app started to crash when I added a directory from my phone, and I have only two devices : my laptop and my phone.

I do not see an id conflict, please re-open.

(I'm new to syncthing, I don't expect a software to panic on an error you can make me fix by telling me a single simple line, please re-open the issue. It may not be an issue as you understand it, but it's at least an UX issue that needs to be fixed, I mean, my mother won't be able to use a software that crash and don't tell how to recover on simple errors, she won't be able to write english on a forum or whatever).

Bests
The discussion on this working out the issue should happen on the forum, so this will not be reopened until we work out the actual cause so there is a concrete thing to fix.
Sorry to report issue.
Every potential bug should first be debugged and understood in the forum, unless you know exactly what the cause is and what has to be fixed.
I disagree; a panic is a bug, and we should have an open ticket on it regardless of not yet understanding the root cause.

Sure, lets leave this to rot eternally then. 

For all that I know the user might have edited the config by hand and caused this. Is it still a bug in that case? 

That's why this needs a conversation on the forum first, as this just talks about consequences, not the details how this happened.

I don't see how a manual config edit could possibly result in this. I've seen the opposite error (panic when starting non-existent folder) because one part of the code looks in the (a?) global config object and another uses the folder config passed from the change event. I wouldn't be surprised if this was similar.

That would be a one-off crash, not repeated after restart. 

This implies the config is screwed. 

It's perfectly possible that we screw the config, yet we need the config, potentially the logs, the user needs to try X then try Y then report feedback if it fixed issue etc, which potentially helps us understand the cause, for which the forum is a much more suitable medium until we understand whats happening and then can reasonably quantify the problem and raise a work item.
Every folder has a different id in the current config with which it fails to start up?
If you disable auto-accept by manually tweaking the config, does it fix itself?
RIght, can you re-enable manually, post full log from stdout and post your config?

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

body:
Can you run with this build:
(windows)
https://build.syncthing.net/viewLog.html?buildId=24061&buildTypeId=Syncthing_BuildWindows&tab=artifacts
(crosscompiled)
https://build.syncthing.net/viewLog.html?buildId=24060&buildTypeId=Syncthing_BuildLinuxCross&tab=artifacts

Once it completes, and provide full logs once more, thanks.

Please try the build from https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/5067 once it rolls off.
Please remove all extra folders, and just leave the one that was crashing (or get it back into the state where it crashes), as it's getting hard to read.

https://build.syncthing.net/viewLog.html?buildId=24078&buildTypeId=Syncthing_BuildLinuxCross

The build URL is in the collapsed checks section
Thanks, I now understand what the problem is, and I have a hunch why it happens. Let me produce one last build to verify my idea.

See 
https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/5067. 
You'll find a link to the latest build, in this pull request by expanding the checks section and clicking on the `Linux, Cross` build.

issue.title: lib/config: Copy inputs and copy config outputs

issue.body:
This is a guess as to what could be the cause for #5063.

In the last debug logs the relevant part was:

```
[GXVUP] 22:26:43 INFO: Existing folder default false
[GXVUP] 22:26:43 INFO: Existing folder gdrxc-frazc false
[GXVUP] 22:26:43 INFO: Existing folder jjnhx-nhqzq false
[GXVUP] 22:26:43 INFO: Missing folder ewa2m-zcpje

// CommitConfiguration in the model coming in:

[GXVUP] 22:26:43 INFO: from folder map[
default:...
ewa2m-zcpje:...
gdrxc-frazc:...


[GXVUP] 22:26:43 INFO: to folder map[
ewa2m-zcpje:...
gdrxc-frazc:...
jjnhx-nhqzq:...
default:...

[GXVUP] 22:26:43 INFO: Adding folder "test1" (jjnhx-nhqzq)
```

So `ewa2m-zcpje` was introduced, but it somehow overwrote an existing folders spot in the config.

body: Can you try the build from https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/5069 and see if you can repro?
@spicedreams panic trace?

I am finding that just 1 machine is suddenly getting these panics (of 4 machines all with 0.14.48 on Linux Mint 18.3).
The panic occurs with the last <folder ... > ... block in config.xml. If I remove that last block, then the panic occurs on the new last . I have removed 3 last folders sequentially now; the result is always the same, the new last is identified as 'already running' and syncthing panics.
I don't think I use auto-accept at all, so I don't know if this is the same problem as above. When I remove a block from config.xml, for the few minutes that syncthing stays running, it gets proposals to re-introduce the folder from a couple of other machines.
sorry, got some more information and could not edit my first post so I have deleted and re-added it here...
When I re-added the <folder ...> blocks I had removed, the panic started ocurring in the second to last block. 
file:///home/graham/.config/syncthing/panic-20180722-184410.log
damn, drag & drop does not seem to have attached the panic log. Trying again...

[panic-20180722-184410.log](https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/files/2216770/panic-20180722-184410.log)
here we go...
